agent_recommendations.title: Census Methodology Documentation Review
agent_recommendations.key_finding: Census Bureau explicitly warns against combining vintages; major methodology shifts at 2010 and 2020

agent_recommendations.title: Statistical Transition Analysis
agent_recommendations.key_finding: Significant level shift at 2009-2010 (p=0.003), but structural break test non-significant; 29:1 variance ratio across vintages

agent_recommendations.title: Cross-Vintage Comparability Assessment
agent_recommendations.key_finding: 3/4 comparability indicators positive; ND pattern shared with similar states; 93% ACS validation

areas_of_agreement: All agents recommend caution when extending the time series
All agents support Option B (extend with caveats) or Option C (hybrid approach)
All agents acknowledge significant methodology changes at vintage transitions
All agents note sample size limitations constrain definitive conclusions
areas_of_disagreement: Agent 1 flags Census Bureau guidance against combining vintages; Agents 2-3 find patterns suggesting extension may be valid
Agent 2 finds significant level shift at 2009-2010; Agent 3 attributes similar patterns to Bakken boom economics
Agent 1 does not support Option A (corrections); Agents 2-3 are uncertain about correction feasibility

key_tensions.description: Census Bureau explicitly warns against combining vintages, yet statistical and comparability evidence suggests extension may be defensible for research purposes

key_tensions.tension: Methodology effect vs. Bakken boom timing
key_tensions.description: The 2009-2010 vintage transition coincides closely with the Bakken oil boom onset, making it impossible to cleanly attribute level shift to either cause
Agent 2 found significant level shift (d=1.56) but structural break test was non-significant - tests give conflicting signals

synthesis.synthesizer_rationale: Weight of evidence supports feasibility of time series extension with explicit documentation of caveats. The combination of (1) shared patterns across similar states, (2) coherent response to known events, (3) 93% ACS validation, and (4) non-significant structural break tests suggests that methodology changes may not dominate over genuine demographic dynamics. However, (1) Census Bureau institutional guidance, (2) significant level shift at 2009-2010, and (3) extreme variance heterogeneity warrant explicit documentation and sensitivity analyses.
synthesis.recommended_option_rationale: Use n=25 (2000-2024) for primary analysis to maximize power, but report sensitivity analyses using n=15 (2010-2024) as robustness check. Document vintage transitions explicitly in methods section.
synthesis.phase_b_recommendation: Defer decision to external review by ChatGPT 5.2 Pro. If corrections are deemed necessary, Phase B investigation of splicing/adjustment methods should proceed.

review_requests_for_external_ai.question: Given the Census Bureau's explicit guidance against combining vintages and the significant level shift detected at 2009-2010, is Option C (hybrid approach with sensitivity analyses) methodologically defensible?
review_requests_for_external_ai.context: The level shift may reflect either methodology change or Bakken boom timing

review_requests_for_external_ai.question: How should we interpret the discrepancy between the significant t-test/Welch test (p=0.003) and non-significant Chow test (p=0.45) at the 2009-2010 transition?
review_requests_for_external_ai.context: These tests have different null hypotheses and power characteristics

review_requests_for_external_ai.question: Given the 29:1 variance ratio across vintages, what statistical approaches should be used if we proceed with extension?
review_requests_for_external_ai.context: Standard time series methods assume homoscedasticity

review_requests_for_external_ai.question: Should we proceed to Phase B (correction methods investigation) or is the evidence sufficient to proceed with Option B or C?
review_requests_for_external_ai.context: Phase B would investigate splicing, chain-linking, and adjustment methods
